Entry.2:
Two American soldiers were walking up the Main Road toward Albany Wards Picture Show Said one American. Wal, I guess you could drop England in one corner of America and not notice it 

Garn, said one of the Aussies – there is plenty of spare land here pointing to the high hill near by with the map of Australia dug deeply into the chalk on its side. There is that much – land about here that they have to pile it up in heaps! to get rid of it. The Yank appeared to be thinking for awhile!
Entry.3:
Easter Monday

Bank Holiday
Left Glasgow and went to Edinburgh. Saw most of what is worth seeing in the Royal Mile – in the old part of the City In the afternoon Cpl Holm & I went down to the big Forth Bridge which is said to be the greatest bit of steel bridge building in the world. Spent an enjoyable day.

1918
Entry.4:
Tuesday
I had a further look around the city in the morning and went into a kind of Social in the afternoon given to a party from the Club by Mrs Martin a few miles out from Edinburgh. We spent a very pleasant afternoon.
Entry.5:
Wednesday

Left Edinburgh about 1. P.M. & went to Glasgow In the afternoon Dr Eddy & I went to the Municipal Building to have a look at them. It is a beautiful Building. Saw my friend Marie Cameron there. In the evening went went to Govan to see some people named Boyd. They proved to be very nice Sociable & homely people. Left Glasgow about 10. P.M.

1918
Entry.7: Arrived Euston about 10. a.m. Went to Leytonstone about mid day. Left Waterloo about 6. P.M. Arrived Hurdcott about 9.30 P.M. The end of a very pleasant Furlough especially as regards my visit to Scotland.
Entry.9:
after Easter

Very showery weather. Nothing of much account doing in the afternoon took a walk with Sgt. Lench into Barford. Had a lunch there & got back to camp about 4 P.M.

1918
Entry.10:
Monday

Same old camp routine Still on massage treatment Went Pictures at night Nothing of importance doing.
Entry.11:
Tuesday
Nothing special doing. Went to Concert at night given by No. 4 Command Concert party calling themselves the owls. It was very good indeed I have been specially recommended for discharge

1918
Entry.12:
Wednesday

Just the same old camp routine. Went to camp pictures at night & that finished an uneventful day. Beautiful warm weather.
Entry.13:
Thursday
An uneventful day as most are in camp. At night RSM. Smith and I went to a concert given by the Kangaroos – the No. 3 Command Concert party. It was very 
good
 but not so good as that given by the Owls.

1918
Entry.14:
Friday

Nothing of any importance going at all. This is a very dull & uneventful place after being used to so much Military work & bustle in the Field At night Smith & I went to Albany Wards Show. A very medium affair of pictures & Vaudeville
Entry.15:
Saturday

A very Cool Change after bright warm weather. In the evening R.S.M. Smith & I went into Salisbury We went to see a couple of Shows which were fairly good & altogether had a fairly good time.

1918
Entry.16:
Sunday

2 after Easter

Same old Stuff In the afternoon Smith & I went into Dinton a very small village on the South Western Line. Had tea there & afterward went to Church (C.E) in a quaint old Church a mile or so out of the town. A number of the boys who have died at Fovant Hospital are buried in the Church yard.
Entry.17:
Monday

A very uneventful day. The weather continues cold and damp. Smith and I went to Albany Wards Show at night fairly good show. Getting tired of Camp life

1918
Entry.18:
Tuesday

We are having miserable wet weather and it is very cold. There is nothing of interest to note. - Just the same old routine.
Entry.19:
Wednesday

It is still raining & very cold. The news from the French Front continues to be bad. Baillene has been lost & the situation in the North is grave.

1918
Entry.20:
Thursday

Weather still cold and miserable. Things appear to be going not too well at the Front.

Nothing of interest to report in this Camp.
Entry.21:
Friday

Just the same old tale of camp life.

Went to concert at night – which was very good. The Troupe was called 
& 3 all

A nice bright show weather still very cold

1918
Entry.22:
Saturday

Took over No 8 Canteen again today. Things very quiet no news of much importance from France.
Entry.23:
Sunday

3 after Easter

Beastly cold weather. Nothing of importance going. Have not heard anything of my discharge so far. Things appear to be at a dead lock in France.

1918
Entry.24:
Monday

Nothing of importance going. Just the same old camp routine. The weather has at last turned out nice and fine and warm.
Entry.25:
Tuesday

Just jogging along in the same old way. Nice warm weather continues and every where is beginning to look beautiful and green.

1918
Entry.26:
Wednesday

Nothing of importance to note. Just the same old camp life. Things are still going against us on the Western Front particularly in the Northern sector.
Entry.27:
Thursday

Anzac Day was kept up in the Command by sports. Beautiful fine day and the sports are said to have been success-ful.

1918
Entry.28:
Friday

Just the same old camp routine. Things on the French Front still going against us. Nice warm weather.
Entry.29:
Saturday
Went to Salisbury in the afternoon per motor. A very warm pleasant afternoon. Had a fairly good time in town. Went to a couple of show which were fairly good.

1918
Entry.30:
Sunday

A cold miserable day. Still working in the Canteen. Nothing of particular importance going except that things are still going against us at the Front.
Entry.31:
Monday

Same old camp routine. Nothing fresh to report. Have not heard anything more about my Discharge.

1918
Entry.33: Nasty weather again Nothing fresh to report. Still looking after No 8 Canteen.
Entry.34:
Wednesday
I went before a Med: Board today. So far do not know what I am classified. Nothing fresh to report.

1918
Entry.35:
Thursday
Still classified C.1. and carry on with the same old Canteen Duties.

Nothing fresh to report.
Entry.36:
Friday
Things are very deadly in camp. 
My
 Nothing of much importance report from the Front It is thought generally that the Hun will again shortly launch another big attack.

1918
Entry.37:
Saturday
Nothing special to record Beautiful sunny afternoon Things are very quiet in camp and I am just about fed up with things.
Entry.38:
Rogation Sunday
Nothing special doing today. In the afternoon I went for a walk out onto the Dinton Rd – then to Barford and from there back to camp. There is a very beautiful avenue on the Dinton Rd called I believe Dinton Avenue

1918
Entry.39:
Monday
Just the same old Camp routine. I am still looking after No 8 Canteen. Have not heard anything about my Discharge
Entry.40:
Tuesday
A very nasty wet day – rain falling incessantly from morning till night. Nothing fresh going to report.

1918
Entry.41:
Wednesday
Weather much improved today. Just going along in the same old way – the same old camp routine.
Entry.42:
Thursday
Just the same old camp routine. Beautiful weather but things in camp are very slow – giving one a fed up feeling.

1918
Entry.43:
Friday
Still looking after No 8 Canteen Nothing of importance to note
Entry.44:
Saturday
A beautiful fine day Nothing special doing. Went for a stroll down to Barford in the afternoon.

1918 May 12

Sunday

After Ascension

Just the same old Camp Sunday Had a stroll through the woods between our camp and the Dinton Rd in the afternoon Went to a Y.M.C.A. Service in the evening Nice fine weather. Heard today that 2nd Lft Rochester has been killed in France. He was one of our original 1st Coy boy & only
Entry.46:
Nothing of importance to note. In the evening went to a Concert in Camp. Very good.

1918
Entry.47:
Tuesday
Just going along as usual. Still looking after No. 8. Canteen. Weather very warm.
Entry.48:
Wednesday
Just the same old camp routine. Nothing of importance to note.

1918
Entry.49:
Thursday
Nothing much of account to note. Weather is very warm – almost hot at times. Went a concert in the evening given by the Y.M.C.A. party. Very fair
Entry.50:
Friday
Just the same old Camp routine Getting very tired of being in this camp.

1918
Entry.51:
Saturday
Things very quiet in camp. There is just nothing to report. I am still looking after No 8 canteen.
Entry.52:
Whit Sunday
Nothing of much importance to note Australians reported to have taken a Village near Albert and 360 prisoners Very warm weather Went to Service in Y.M. in the evening.

1918
Entry.53:
Whitsun Monday

Bank Holiday
This appears to be something different to what the English people usually have on Whit Monday. Usually there is a holiday but all appear to be working today. Same old Camp routine. Very warm. Air Raid on London last night.
Entry.54:
Whitsun Tuesday
Nothing to report still acting as Canteen Sergt. Nice warm weather.

1918
Entry.55:
Wednesday
Just living in our own little narrow Camp world and hearing nothing much of the doings of the Outside world. Nothing to report.
Entry.56:
Thursday
Nothing of special import. Just the same old camp routine. Weather very chilly again.

1918
Entry.57:
Friday
Went to Salisbury and was Decorated with the M.M. & Bar. All recipients in the Southern Command were Decorated. Gen: Sclater was officiated & altogether it was a big ceremony. Got back to camp about 7.P.M. In the evening. We held a Sgt Social in No 1 Mess. Usual Beer and smoke feast.
Entry.58:
Saturday
Nothing of importance to note. Still carrying on in the Canteen job.

1918
Entry.59:
Thursday
Just the same old Camp Sunday. In the afternoon LCp Trevena, Sap Brown and I went for a walk out onto the Dinton Rd & on to Barford. Saw an old church there part of which dates back to Magna charter.
Entry.60:
Monday
Still nice fine weather. Paraded for Leave and was granted eight days from Friday next. Going to Scotland. Report the the enemy have commenced another offensive in France.

1918
Entry.61:
Tuesday
Reported Germans have made a substantial advance in the Rheims sector advancing 11 miles Nice fine weather. Same old camp life.
Entry.62:
Wednesday
Nothing of importance from here to report Germans still advancing. Weather still nice & fine and hot.

1918
Entry.63:
Thursday
Just jogging along in the same old way. Getting ready today to go on Leave tomorrow.
Entry.64:
Friday
Left Dinton about 9.30 & got to London about midday. Did some business went to see Mr Smith at the office and later went to Leytonstone to see Mrs Smith & Daisy. Stayed with the Smiths for the evening & left for Glasgow at 11.45 P.M.

1918
Entry.65:
Saturday
Arrived Glasgow about 9.45 a.m. Had a clean up & did a bit of business & then went to the office to see my friend Mary Boyd When I got there found that she and her two sisters a friend had a trip arranged to Gourock and expected me to go too so away I went nothing loth. Got back to Glasgow about 9.45 P.M. after an enjoyable day. The girls too enjoyed themselves thoroughly. Very warm weather.
Entry.66:
Sunday
 

1 May 1918

Wednesday

1 After Trinity

Got up late and after breakfast went to Rouken Glen which is a very beautiful place – quite the most beautiful park or public grounds I have seen about Glasgow. In the afternoon I went out to Govan & met with Mary, Georgie & Peggy to some friends place out near the University.

Altogether spent a nice day.

1918
Entry.67:
Monday
Travelled per train to Balloch –thence by boat up Loch Lomond as far as Inversnaid. Took rowing boat across Loch - about two miles & walked down to Tarbet. Took train from there to Glasgow Via the Gare Loch & Loch Long arriving back about 5.30 P.M. The trip was altogether was a very beautiful & enjoyable one. In the evening I visited my friends the Boyds at Govan – altogether had a very enjoyable day.
Entry.68:
Tuesday
Went to Stirling in the morning & returned to Glasgow in the afternoon. Visited the Castle at Stirling also the East & West Church or Black Friars church Went to Shawlands in the evening to see my friends Mrs & Miss Rankin. Altogether had an enjoyable day.

1918
Entry.69:
Wednesday
Travelled per train to Wymiss Bay in the morning thence by boat across to Rothesay – up through the Kyles of Bute as far as Adrishaig via Tarbert & Tin-En-Bough & other places. This is a very beautiful trip mostly through narrow passages with the hills running right down to the waters edge on either side – timbered mostly along the foothills with flowers intermingled & dwellings built here & there & nestling in beautiful surrounding with the hills behind mostly grassy on the sides & rising & terminating in rocky crests. Altogether very beautiful arrived back about 7 P.M.
Entry.70:
Thursday
In the forenoon went out with a party to Brays Engineering works which are very interesting. They are making all kinds of war material amongst which is much for the USA. One Dpt alone where all girls are employed in turning out 40.000 copper bands for 18 pd shells. This firm make all kinds of material rolling & moulding their own metal. Saw some of our aerial bombs being made – standing about 4’ 6" in height & weighing when charged about 250 lbs. Went to the Alhambra at night.

1918
Entry.71:
Friday
Went to a Hospital Fete at Paisley Cross in the afternoon which was rather interesting and later went out to the skating rink with a Canadian Sgt. Came back & went to a Y.M. Social for about an hour & left 
was
 Glasgow about 10. P.M.
Entry.72:
Saturday
Arrived in London 8.5 a.m. Did a little business & then went to Leytonstone to see my friends & left Waterloo 6.P.M. arriving back in camp about 9.30 P.M. feeling fairly tired after a good enjoyable holiday.

1918
Entry.73:
Sunday

2 after Trinity

Not doing very much today takings things easy to get over the tired feeling after coming back from Leave. In the afternoon Sgt Gunner & I went for a stroll through Dinton & Barford. Raining fairly heavy in the forenoon.
Entry.74:
Monday
Resumed duty in the Canteen. Nice fine weather. Nothing of importance to note.

1918
Entry.75:
Tuesday
On Canteen duty Was warned this afternoon that I am for Daft for Brightlingsea in the morning.
Entry.76:
Wednesday
Left Hurdcott about 8. a.m. & arrived at Brightlingsea about 5. P.M. After much changing about on the railway. Having nice fine weather The country about here does not appear to be so nice & fertile as in Wilts.

1918
Entry.77:
Thursday
Doing nothing in particular today. Met a lot of old boys in this Depot. In the evening there was a concert given by some London party. Only just fair Brightlingsea appears a nice little Village - probably about 5,000 inhabitants & boasts a small – very small - shipbuilding yard.
Entry.78:
Friday
Nothing of much importance going. In the evening Sgt. Howlett & I went to the pictures. Nothing else to excite one.

1918
Entry.79:
Saturday
Have not been given any duties so far. Just walking about and having a good time generally.
Entry.80:
Sunday

3 After Trinity

A quiet day in the Depot Church parade in the morning & the rest of the day free.

1918
Entry.81:
Monday
Doing very little just assisting in small details in the Depot Things are very quiet here.
Entry.82:
Tuesday
Haven’t been given a job yet. Nothing of importance to note.

1918
Entry.83:
Wednesday
Squally wet weather – sometimes fine – sometimes raining My feet are treating me fairly badly again & I am having them massaged again. The Disease that has been raging in the Depot appears to have almost died out.
Entry.84:
Thursday
Doing very little work. Things are going along in just the same old way in the Depot. Nothing exciting.

1918
Entry.85:
Friday
Took over Company orderly Sgt job in the morning & hand it over to Sgt. Connell of the 7th F Coy. before night. I am now to be Draft Sgt. Nothing fresh to report Italians reported still doing well against the Austrians.
Entry.86:
Saturday
Nothing of much importance to write about Just the same old camp Life.

1918
Entry.87:
Sunday

4 After Trinity

A rather quiet day in Camp on Sunday Church parade in the morning & not much doing in the afternoon except that a very indifferent Band plays & a lot of the Townspeople come to hear it.
Entry.88:
Monday
Busy to-day getting a Draft of A.E. N.C.O’s ready for France Kept fairly busy all day.

1918
Entry.89:
Tuesday
Busy all day getting an overseas Draft ready for France. Got through about 70. Had a rather heavy day.
Entry.90:
Wednesday
Made a start with another Draft of about 60 today & got them through. The M.O. & R.M.O. kept very busy all day.

1918
Entry.91:
Thursday
Busy all day getting Draft through the Kit store & now have them all complete for France Got through about 170 this week & they are ready to go at any time.
Entry.92:
Friday
Had a fairly easy day. Run a few men through the Dr. Dentist & equipment store. Italians reported still doing well on the Piave

1918
Entry.93:
Saturday
A Draft of 70 odd overseas men got away this evening otherwise my day was fairly quiet & uneventful.
Entry.95:
5 After Trinity

Put a few men through the equipment store in the morning & in the afternoon rode a bike to Clacton – on Sea. It is a very nice little place & I believe very fashionable & gay in times of peace.

1918
Entry.96:
Monday
Very quiet. Got about 40 men away in the afternoon. Italians are doing well according to reports & British & French have had successful minor affairs on the Western Front. Nice fine weather.
Entry.97:
Tuesday
Things quiet for me today as I haven’t had any Draft men to handle. Things just going along in the same old Slow way in the Depot.

1918
Entry.98:
Wednesday
Nothing of much account to report in the Depot. Nice fine weather. I haven’t had any men to put through for Draft during the past two days so I have had a fairly Lazy time
Entry.99:
Thursday
Depot sports held on the flat below the village. Every one appeared to be very well satisfied so they must have been a success

1918
Entry.100:
Friday
Kept fairly busy today getting a Casual Draft ready Nothing of much importance to note. The Aussies have had a successful Stunt on the Somme capturing about 1500 prisoners Italians reported doing well!
Entry.101:
Saturday
Things as usual in the Depot. In the afternoon Sgt Connell & I rode bikes into Colchester & had a nice afternoon. A fete in aid of the Lord Roberts Memorial Fund was the chief attraction & it was well patronized Arrived back in Depot about midnight

1918
Entry.102:
Sunday

6 After Trinity

The usual quiet day in camp. The camp is open on Sunday afternoons & a good many townspeople pay us a visit & listen to the Band. Expect to go to Weymouth tomorrow.
Entry.103:
Monday
Arrived at Weymouth at midnight. Got to London about midday & in the afternoon went out to see some friends at Leytonstone. Left London by the 7 P.M. train for Weymouth.

1918
Entry.104:
Tuesday
Went up for the classification this morning & was again marked C.I. Waiting now for a final Board. Had a look round the town in the evening which appears to be a nice place.
Entry.105:
Wednesday
Nothing in particular doing today. Expect a final Board on Friday Showery weather.

1918
Entry.106:
Thursday
Put in a quiet day. We had exceptionally heavy rain last night and this morning & all day it has been squally Went with Sgt Clark in the evening to the Pavillion Theatre & saw Who’s the woman. Only just fair Had some tea in town & got back to camp 9 P.M.
Entry.107:
Friday
Went up for Medical Colonel Newmarch presiding. Do not know the result yet. Things going along in the same camp-like way.

1918
Entry.108:
Saturday
Light factiques – Battn parade & games for the Troops in the morning. Sgt Clark & I went to Easton & Portland in the afternoon & had a very pleasant time. Went to Pictures at night which were only middling.
Entry.109:
Sunday

7 After Trinity

Just the usual camp routine Nothing of much importance going Wet & squally Sgt Clark & I went for a stroll down town at night but were home early.

1918
Entry.110:
Monday
News through that D16 carrying returns from here has been Torpedoed. Believed all saved. Nothing of much importance going or rather the Germans have started an offensive against the French but are not making much progress.
Entry.111:
Tuesday
Chief excitement was the returned of the boys who were on the Torpedoed D16. I was one of the Conducting N.C.O.s & we had them all in camp about 9.20 P.M. looking rather rough in all kind of clothing

1918
Entry.112:
Wednesday
Was drafted onto Boat Roll D18 today & transferred into No 3 Company. Expect to leave about Sunday A wet squally day Went to the Palace & Montys Flapper played Fairly good.
Entry.113:
Thursday
Just the same old Camp Routine The one absorbing topic is "Who will be on Carrier D.18. final Roll. Nasty wet weather.

1918
Entry.114:
Friday
Left Westham this afternoon & went to Monte Video Expect to be on D18 Carrier Supplementary Roll. Nasty wet weather Reported French & American troops doing very well.
Entry.115:
Saturday
Moved from Westham to Monte Video yesterday where I am on the Supplementary Roll today on D18 We may sail tomorrow French and American troops doing very well near Rheims where it is reported they have captured 16,000 & some guns

1918
Entry.116:
Sunday

8 After Trinity

Left Monte Video in Motors & went to Weymouth Station & left there about 2.30 P.M. Arrived at Bristol about 5.30 & "Avonmouth" 6 PM. and next straight on board of the Boonah. The country we travelled through from Weymouth to Bristol was very fine & beautiful – every thing looking at its best The country after passing Upway and again about "Freshford on Avon" & at Bath was particularly beautiful

Had a good time.
Entry.117:
Monday
Left Avonmouth 
about
 early in the afternoon & ran to Barrydock where we waited for a few hours picked up two Q boats & the Marmora as Escort & left about 6.30 The weather is not at all pleasant & the sea fairly rough. The Marmora is an Orient Boat fitted as an auxillary Cruiser & appears to carry about 8 guns. Barrydock is a very important coaling station on the Welsh side of Bristol Channel & appears to be very busy just at present.

1918
Entry.118:
Tuesday
Weather rather wet with heavy rain squals. Am under Captains orders on Bridge keeping look-out for Submarines. About 2.45 P.M. Marmora which was lying close in on our Port Bows – was torpedoed & sank in 65 min: Two Q boats that were escorting gave chase to the Submarine & dropped a lot of Depth charges but I think with one effect except to frighten Fritz away from us. Reported all hands saved but some must have killed by the explosion as it was very heavy. I was on watch at the time & saw it happen one of our Escort have left us with the crew & of the Marmora & one is still with us.
Entry.119:
Wednesday
Proceeding well – so far no further mishap. This afternoon after wishing us luck our Escort left us. Sea rough all day with heavy wind & rain squals A good many of the boys sea. sick. We appear to be off the usual track as we have only sighted one boat since leaving & that a Destroyer.

1918
Entry.120:
Thursday
Nothing unusual happening. The weather has cleared up considerably the sea is much more smooth. Reported by Wireless that Submarines have been sighted about a days sail ahead. A Large ships passed close about 10.30 P.M.
Entry.121:
Friday
Weather getting considerably warmer. We passed through a large school of whales this morning of a large Kind. One was almost run down by us & then passed quite close by the Port-side of the ship. A little Wireless war news through Franco American army doing well. Nothing else of importance.

1918
Entry.122:
Saturday
Nothing eventful to note. Reported that submarines are opperating rather plentifully in these waters – several ships being sunk & some submarines sighted. Rather an anxious time & a very strict lookout has to be Kept. Reported good news from the front in France. First pay day at sea.
Entry.123:
Sunday

9 After Trinity

An uneventful day. Church Parade in morning. Weather getting uncomfortably warm. The boat is by no means clean & it is not too comfortable as one cannot find a clean spot to rest in. The sea is very smooth with just a little ground swell.

1918
Entry.124:
Monday
Still getting along safely. The sea is very calm & the weather very warm. No news though about anything We have not sighted a boat of any description for days past. We appear to be right off the tracks of any boats.
Entry.125:
Tuesday
Making a good trip but nothing very interesting happening No war news through So do not know how things are going. Still on Submarine lookout on Bridge.

1918
Entry.126:
Wednesday
Nothing very exciting Sighted a convoy of four boats bound Northward from Sierra Leone. Sighted a few whales – porpoise Weather unpleasantly warm.
Entry.127:
Thursday
Nothing exciting to mark the incoming of the new month. Sighted a Spanish boat coming from Sierra Leone. Thousands of Flying Fish to be seen – some of them of very brilliant colors. Weather very hot. Making a good voyage.

1918
Entry.128:
Friday
An uneventful day. Very hot & sultry. A boat coming apparently from Sierra Leone passed close by. About the only thing of interest is to watch the Flying fish of which there are thousands here about.
Entry.129:
Saturday
A very quiet uneventful day. The weather continues to be very hot making things very uncomfortable. No news of any kind through.

1918
Entry.130:
Friday
Cloudy & squally with a choppy sea & a fairly heavy swell. Church Parade in the morning & nothing else of much importance. Expect to get Sierra Leone tomorrow
Entry.131:
Monday

Bank Holiday
Reported carrier D17 torpedoed a few lives lost. Arrived Sierra Leone about 7.30 A.M. & left about 5 P.M. about 10 fairly large boats lying at anchor & an old Battle Ship. The place does not appear to be very large but it is rather picturesque & pretty. High ridgged hills rise almost from the water & houses can be seen away up on slopes. There is a fair sized English Garrison The growth of course appears to be semi tropical. Natives rowed the canoes across with bananas oranges – mangroves etc

1918
Entry.132:
Tuesday
Cloudy with occasionally heavy rain & wind All awnings taken down in anticipation of a gale tonight rising and a fairly heavy sea running.
Entry.133:
Wednesday
Reported "Ambulance" Transport torpedoed & 123 lives lost. Should have crossed the "Line" some time today We are having remarkably cool weather considering our position Just a nice lively sea & a cool breez. Nothing of importance to note.

1918
Entry.134:
Friday
A beautiful fine cool day with a light breeze blowing. Nothing of any importance reported. We "lifted" the Southern Cross last night – the first time I have seen it for nearly four years. A very welcome sight.
Entry.135:
Friday
Good news from the Western Front The Allies appear be pushing on a long front & report advancing several miles capturing 100 guns & 14,000 prisoners. Beautiful weather and all going well. 

1918
Entry.136:
Saturday
Beautiful fine weather No further news from the Front. Things going well but journey getting very monotonous. Bad head for about a week – feels like Gas effects.
Entry.137:
Sunday

11 After Trinity

Just the same old ship life – things going well but nothing unusual to report still getting nice cool weather.

1918
Entry.138:
Monday
A cool and cloudy day Nothing of special interest to note. We are having a very easy and lazy time – nothing to do practically but lay about & read
Entry.139:
Tuesday
The same old Boat routine – 3 meals per day – ships Inspection and put in the remainder of the day as best one can.

1918
Entry.140:
Wednesday
"Concert at night"

A very considerable swell developing & a rough choppy sea running. The weather is now very much cooler than in the early part of the voyage & one can do comfortably with a blanket at night.
Entry.141:
Thursday
A fairly heavy sea running and rather a heavy swell. Weather cloudy and inclined to be wet – just a little rain! Boat only doing about 
8
 miles per hour owing the heavy head wind & sea.

1918 August 16

Friday
A very nice fine day & a beautiful sea with just a little roll. Nothing important happening on the boat. Another concert at night to cheer the lads up. Good war news. Reported 30,000 prisoners & 1,000 Guns since
Entry.143:
Saturday
Nothing of special import. Beautiful weather & everything going well. Expect to reach the Cape about Monday. A little war news but nothing of great importance We are making a little progress.

1918
Entry.144:
Sunday

12 After Trinity

Nothing exciting happening. Usual Church Services in morning & "sing song" Service at night & afterward a discussion of ways & means of getting a living after returning home. O.C. Major Ross prisided & a few legislators on "would be
s
" spoke.
Entry.145:
Monday
Arrived Cape Town & tied up about 10.30 AM. Had leave into town in the afternoon with Sgt Brindly R.Q.M.S. Clarke Sgt Rees. Took a tram trip to Camp Bay & back via Koof Nek . It is a very nice & interesting trip. In the evening we went to see Three Weeks at the Opera House. The Acting was only just fair. Cape Town appears to be a fairly well built little City but I was rather disappointed on my first visit Arrived back at Boat about 11.30 P.M. 

1918
Entry.146:
Tuesday
Stationed as Piquet in Police station
ed
 till 10 P.M. Got very little time off. Had a look around town with Sgt Brindly for awhile in the afternoon & for a couple of hours in the evening. A very hot day. The people of Cape Town do not to me appear to be very hospitable - at least not toward the Australians. But I may be mistaken as I have not seen much of them. However appearances do not give one a good impression. Got back off duty to boat about 11 P.M. very tired & with the usual headache
Entry.147:
Wednesday
Left Cape Town about 11.30 a.m. Soon after leaving Port we ran into a very dense fog & had to slow down for about an hour "Sussex" left just in front of us & we passed her just before dark. Past a Boat about 9 P.M. Beautiful clear night Left one man in Hospital.

1918
Entry.148:
Thursday

An uneventful day. There is a fairly heavy swell at times and the weather is very much cooler. At times the wind is almost cold. We are making good steady progress doing a little over 10 Kts pr hour.
Entry.149:
Friday
A fairly heavy breeze & a rising sea getting up to quite a considerable roll by bed time. Nothing extraordinary though – just a few things being dislodged (seasick ch – Serg?) R.M.

1918
Entry.150:
Saturday
A nice fine day & the sea has calmed down considerably only a small roll now running. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.151:
Sunday

13 After Trinity

A beautiful fine day with a very cool breeze blowing. Good War news. British advancing capturing Albert & gathering in 14,000 prisoners. About 10.30 A.M. one of the Mental cases ran amok & climbed to the cross-head on the mast a height of about 50’ A couple of men went up after him & after a short struggle he fell striking on of the winches & was killed instantly. Buried in the afternoon!

1918
Entry.152:
Monday
Nothing unusual to note. Good War news continues to come through. Capt. Hunter late of Mawsons Arctic Expedition gave a Lecture with Lantern illustrations Interesting. Making good progress with fine weather.
Entry.153:
Tuesday
Just the same old ship routine. Reported things going well on all Fronts "Albert" re-captured & British troops advanced well well forward of that position – taking fair number prisoners.

1918
Entry.154:
Wednesday
Making good progress in fine weather & favourable Sea Good news still coming through from all Fronts Good advances and many prisoners. Concert at night.
Entry.155:
Thursday
Nothing of great importance to note. A Little Boxing in the afternoon to keep the boys fit. Nice fine weather & a beautiful sea. Good news continues to come from Western Front N. Zealanders enter northern outskirts of Bapaume. French & Americans doing well.

1918
Entry.156:
Friday
A little war news through per wireless via Mauritius. Still progressing well on all Fronts. Nothing startling on Board still getting nice fine weather and making good progress – about 250 miles per day.
Entry.157:
Saturday
Making better progress than usual owing to a strong breeze almost astern & a fairly heavy sea running This is the roughest seas for the voyage so far

1918
Entry.159:
14 After Trinity

Another sad case of 
suicide
 today. following on that of Sunday last. One of the lads named Ray threw himself over board in spite of all efforts to pick him up he was lost. We are having rather rough seas now but the wind and waves are in our favour being almost astern We passed the island of St Paul at about 2 – 3 P.M. A barren rock covered with a thin layer of sand & perhaps a few miles in length Usual Church Services.
Entry.160:
Monday
The wind has no way abated & the sea is fairly rough with a heavy sea. About 8 P.M. there was a fairly heavy thunderstorm but we appear to have missed the worst of it. No war news.

1918 September 3

Tuesday
A nice sunny day with a fair wind & swell. Still steering about 10 kts. & everything going well. Everybody appears to be getting tired of the journey and all will be glad when it is finished.
Entry.161:
Wednesday
Still getting good news from the Front where things appear to be going very well with the Allies. Nothing of importance to note on board. Reported Sir John Forrest died en route for England.

1918
Entry.162:
Thursday
We still have a fair breeze – bright weather - & a nice lively sea. Things going well – but journey getting very monotonous.
Entry.163:
Friday
A bright sunny day and nothing of importance happening on the boat. Good news continues to come through from the Western Front where all troops of the Allies appear to be advancing on all Fronts.

1918
Entry.164:
Saturday
Good news continues to come through principally from the French 
and
 Front where the enemy are reported in full flight. British doing well also. Nice fine weather & things going well.
Entry.165:
Sunday

15 After Trinity

Reported British advancing all along the Line in several places being back in the old positions evacuated in March. Beautiful weather & seas. Expect to be in Fremantle early in the morning.

1918
Entry.166:
Monday
Arrived Fremantle about 7.30 am. About 140 men were dropped here & the remainder were given Leave in the afternoon. Sgt Clark Brindley Rees & another Sgt & I went per motor to Perth where we spent a couple of hours. Perth appears to be a nice little City – also Fremantle. Had an enjoyable afternoon & got back to the Boat about 7. P.M.
Entry.167:
Tuesday
Left Port about 7.30 A.M. "Barambali D37" went out in Front of us carrying troops apparently for England. A beautiful day & nice calm sea. Everything appears to be going well on the Western Front the Allies advancing everywhere.

1918
Entry.168:
Wednesday
Making slow progress in beautiful weather & a nice sea. Passed Albany shortly after lunch time. We are running fairly close to the coast & can see it as far as the eye can reach. Nothing of importance happening on board.
Entry.169:
Thursday
A dull day with a freshening breeze and Sea. Fairly heavy rain in the evening We are now well into the "Bight". Good news continues from Western Front though things are getting quieter there. Nothing of importance on the Boat.

1918
Entry.170:
Friday
A nice bright day but nothing of import to note. The boat is travelling very slowly since leaving the West and at the present rate of speed it will be late Mon: before we reach Port. Good news continues from the Front but things are much quieter.
Entry.171:
Saturday
A very quiet and uneventful day. A nice bright day & a fairly heavy swell. No War news. Making very slow time – about 9 Knots per hour.

1918
Entry.172:
Sunday

16 After Trinity

We are in sight of a good deal of Coast here again this evening and are amongst several Light houses & we must be nearing Port Nothing particular happening.
Entry.173:
Monday
Arrived Port Adelaide about 9.30 A.M. Went on shore at midday & were entertained at Lunch by the V.A.D. Nurses who gave us a beautiful dinner. In the afternoon Sgt Brindley, Clarke & I went to Adelaide & in the evening to Prospect to see Mr & Mrs Le Messurier Very nice people. Adelaide impresses one favorably. Today was rather a Gala day in aid of the 7 War Loan Also a big effort was being made to obtain recruits. Got back to Boat about midnight

1918
Entry.174:
Tuesday
Left the Boat about 9.30 A.M. & travelled to National Park in the Mount Lofty Ranges – getting out at Belair. We were again entertained by the V.A.Ds & some of the other local people. We were splendidly treated & had a very enjoyable day indeed. Got back to the Boat about 3 P.M. & pulled put about 5 P.M. The people of Adelaide have done everything in their power to make our visit a pleasant one & have truly succeeded in doing so. We were taken for a motor drive while at National Park & the trip was a very pleasant one driving through natural bush.
Entry.175:
Wednesday
Making good progress with fair weather and a smooth sea Nothing of importance to note. No war news. In sight of the coast all day.

1918
Entry.176:
Thursday
Passed Cape Otway about 8.30 A.M. Entered Port Phillip Heads about 3 P.M. Anchored near Port Melbourne about 6.30 P.M. Excitement seems to be running right through boat. It is a fine homely sight to see the numerous lights along the foreshore of a house. Port once more & a relief to know that we are at our sea journeys end.
Entry.177:
Friday
Disembarked about 10 A.M. & were taken in Motors to No 4 Rest Camp. The Melbourne people gave us 
a fine
 reception The streets being thronged with people who fairly covered us with flowers cigarettes sweets flags etc: The Lord Mayor was on the steps at the Town Hall waiting to shake hands with the boys as they were driven past & tender an official reception. We left Melbourne about 1.20 P.M. by special train. We were given a fine dinner at the Rest Station by the V.A.D. Nurses.

1918 September 21

Saturday
We had a good trip over in the Hospital train arriving at Sydney about 10 a.m. & were driven in Motor Cars to the Bouffet in the Domain People thronged the streets from the Central to the Domain as in Melbourne but taken in all the Melbourne was the better of the two. Met Sis & young Jack at the Central & Ruby & Rowley, Madge. Mary & Bill & Brian at the Went to Brodie & Lettes & stayed for the Evening also dad & Jim came to see me there. Stayed at 204 Victoria St for the night. Feel very pleased to be home once more
Entry.178:
Sunday

17 After Trinity

Breakfast in bed – lazed til dinner – after – walked down as far as Lady McQuaries chair. Sudden heavy rain storm caught us. warships close in. Took refuge in looking at old when Dad Jim & little Jack came along. Looked together then. Rain ceased by closing time. Walked home – Dad with us to St Mary’s. - more rain – walked across to Oxford St to St John’s Paddington: Rev Keith Miller – then home.

1918 September 23

Monday
Lovely morning

Reported at Randwick at 10 A.M.

Looked up 1st &
Entry.179:
boys while waiting - saw Sprs Calvett & Healey also.

Down town – bought farmers – another sudden drenching rain storm then beautifully fine.

Out to then back to Victoria St
Entry.181:
To Randwick again en route for St Georges Heights met Sgt Brindley Spr page 

 Arnold’s father

 at Blind Institution for Mrs McDonald called to see Dad at Mrs Cahills Down to Central for a stroll

1918
Entry.184:
Friday
After tea down to see Dad at Elizabeth Street. Later walked to Central & then up to Liverpool St to - then walked home Dad coming as far as Blind Institution
Entry.185:
Saturday
Went again before the M.O. in the morning Have to go to Randwick for eye test & boots Delivered parcel Neutral Bay for Mrs McDonald from W.O. Smith Blighty and France. Went home with Sgt Brindley & had Lunch. Came back home and after tea Ruby & I went into the City* Arrived back about 10 P.M. after pleasant Evening

* Went to Watsons Bay & then to city by Boat.

1918
Entry.186:
Sunday

18 After Trinity

Went to the Domain this morning to see some more of the boys come home. In the afternoon went with Ruby to the Zoo "Taronga" & spent a very pleasant few hours.

The New Zoo is a very fine turnout all the animals being allowed freedom almost in the native state in large enclosures Arrived back about - 6 P.M. had tea & put in the rest of the evening writing etc: mostly the latter.

Met Cpl Turnley – saw Anderson
Entry.188:
Went to Randwick in the morning & was measured for surgical boots. In the afternoon saw the eye specialist & have to report back in a fortnights time. Ruby & I went to Carey St later in the evening

1918
Entry.189:
Tuesday
Went to A.A.H. Mosman this morning & got 13 days Leave granted came back to 204 Victoria St & Ruby and I went out to Carey St later in the evening. Expect to Leave for Canberra in the morning.
Entry.190:
Wednesday
We took motor from our digs to Central & took train at 9.45 a.m. Madge and Neila came to see us off Arrived Goulburn about 3.30 P.M. & left there about 4.40 P.M. Arrived Queanbeyan about 9. P.M. and motored out to Canberra. Had a good trip up but very slow. Found all home well. Very keen weather. Good news from all Fronts. News Confirmed that Bulgaria has turned it in.

1918
Entry.191:
Thursday
Got up late and did nothing in particular except just stroll about the place. Had a look along the River and put in a lazy day generally. Good news continues to come from all Fronts.
Entry.192:
Friday
Just mooched about home and in the afternoon Dorrie Ruby and I went across to Duntroon where I saw a few of the old boys. Good news still from Fronts.
Entry.193:
Mother Dorrie. Ruth Ruby and I went to Cotter in the afternoon per motor & had a very enjoyable afternoon. The Weir at the Cotter River is complete to a depth of about 76’ and there is a fine flow of water running over the top. Work there is now stopped.

Sunday 6th 

Layed in till late Got up and went down to River with Mac & Malkie & had a row in the boat. In the afternoon Mother Ruby & I went to Upper Canberra to a Memorial Service to George Porter killed in France. Had a stroll around later & a Sing Song at night and that is about all. Nice fine weather Sgt Shaw to tea -? from .
Entry.195:
19 After Trinity

1918 October 7

Monday
Heavy rain for a few hours. In the afternoon Ruby – Mac & Malk & I went for a row on the River. There is nothing in particular to note. Things are still going well on all Fronts.
Entry.196:
Tuesday
Lovely morning. Went across to Acton for mail – saw 2 or 3 members French Commission – I bought Two stamps walked round past administrators nearly to Hospital. Hot. Miss Chace Clarke home with Ruth welcome at Canberra

1918
Entry.197:
Wednesday
Ray over in afternoon car about for Queanbeyan. On to Goulburn Mrs rough trip
Entry.198:
Thursday
Left Sydney by the 4.45 P.M. & got to Nowra about 9 P.M. where we were given a welcome by the Welcome Com: at the Station and on reaching Nowra in the Motor was given a Civic welcome by the Mayor. Got to Sydney from Queanbeyan about 6 A.M. & went out to Waverly where we stayed till afternoon. Good News continues from all Fronts

1918
Entry.199:
Friday
Slept most of the day at least we didn’t do anything of importance.
Entry.200:
Saturday
A Welcome home - also a wedding breakfast at Selwood – by relations & friends of Ruby’s. A very nice and thoughtful little affair. Good news comes in from all Fronts. Nice bright weather.

1918
Entry.202:
20 After Trinity

Left Nowra by the 4.30 train got to Sydney about 9 P.M. & so ended a very enjoyable holiday. Special editions with "Right across" headings about Germany accepting the Allies terms of Peace.
Entry.203:
Monday
Reported back to 21st A.A.H.Mosman this morning. Got out door patients pass. Went to Randwick. Saw Eye specialist. Report back to him this day week. Good news continues to come through from all Fronts.

1918 October 15

Tuesday
Did not much in particular. In the afternoon Ruby & I went down to the City & did a little business also went out to Newtown & saw Sis and the boys. Good war news continuing to come through.

 

2 October 1918

Wednesday
Entry.204:
Wednesday
Started the day by missing the morning train. Caught the 4.45 P.M. & went to Nowra & out to Selwood reaching there about 11 P.M. feeling rather tired. Saw reinforcement march through City Good news from all Fronts.

1918
Entry.205:
Thursday
A very warm windy day. Got up late and the principal event I think was that Arch and I went fishing and caught two fish about this length Good news continues to come from all Fronts.
Entry.206:
Friday
Today the same as yesterday – lazing about and having a good time generally. Reported Germans evacuating the whole of the Belgian Coastline Good news coming in from all Fronts.

1918
Entry.207:
Saturday
Put in the day pottering about the farm. Hilled a few rows of potatoes in the morning and in the afternoon Arch & I did a little fishing in the Currumbene & I caught one fish as the result of our efforts. Good news continues from all Fronts. Lille has been evacuated by the enemy - occupied 5th Army
Entry.208:
Sunday

21 After Trinity

assistant housekeeper Muriels Sunday off

In to town after tea stayed at Fighting Macs service at School of Arts.

1918
Entry.211:
Wednesday
Home 4.50 pm train out by car

Found Uncle Bob here
Entry.213:
Friday
Heavy windy day – down creek on Jennings boat with Arch & young Bill – 4 fish – oysters

Not back after 9 pm dad & uncle from nearly as bad
Entry.215:
Sunday

22 After Trinity

Old Ray gone – search in to town about 6 pm stayed with Mrs Poole 

Up to Dagons for supper steak salt up junction Benny to Deborne street – back by Junction.
Entry.218:
Wednesday
Back 4.50 train Mrs M to meet at station – stayed Pats.

1918
Entry.219:
Thursday
To Mayfield. Old Ray knew where he was going too. Stan & a Mr arriving same time - about midday

new milking machines

Stroll round paddock
Entry.220:
Friday
Back to Nowra – Jacks way. News of Turkey’s acceptance.

Home about tea time.

1918
Entry.221:
Saturday
Wet. To town with Arch & Ena - Wints coach. Billiards etc
Entry.222:
Sunday

23 After Trinity

Muriels Sunday off

Housemaid.

Jimmy Sinclair to tea wrote Ruth etc

1918
Entry.223:
Monday
To town again with Arch & piebald horse.
Entry.224:
Tuesday
20 pals for lunch 

en route for Sydney

Austrias good news confirmed.
